awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: Local adaptation of wild bees to  human-dominated landscapes
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The world has experienced drastic human-driven changes to the landscape, which include mass conversion of natural habitats to agriculture. These changes are a primary driver of global biodiversity loss and altered ecosystem function. In the tropics, deforestation is largely a product of land conversion to pasture for cattle grazing and ranching. This landscape-level simplification has implications for the quantity and quality of the habitat available for wildlife. However, not all species are equally vulnerable to human disturbance and landscape simplification. Accounting for differences in how organisms respond to stressors enhances the effectiveness of management and conservation plans. This project asks how pasturelands versus natural areas affect how stingless bees, a key pollinator group of the Neo-tropics, respond to pesticides that are currently widespread in the environment. A foundational component of this research is capacity building and training for under-represented students both in the US and Colombia, with a focus on future Latinx researchers and leaders. 

This research will evaluate whether the stingless bee Tetragonisca angustula is locally adapted to different landscape contexts and whether this influences its response to an acute stressor. To address these questions, the fellow will conduct a fully factorial reciprocal-transplant of wild-caught bee colonies in Colombia from simplified landscapes, dominated by pastureland, and complex landscapes, characterized primarily by natural areas. Before deployment, bee colonies will be divided, with half experimentally exposed to pesticides at field-realistic concentrations, while the other half receive a pesticide-free control solution. The foraging patterns of each colony will be monitored in terms of what plants are being visited, the quality of the pollen they collect, and the concentration of additional pesticides they encounter in the field. Additionally, the fellow will evaluate whether the landscape context, both in terms of origin and destination, influences bee behavior and pollination services. These findings will inform policy makers about the impact of landscape simplification on bee health and pollination services, and determine the need for context-dependent management plans. Furthermore, the fellow will train underrepresented  minority undergraduate researchers on experimental design and execution, as well as conduct a series of one-day workshops aimed at breaking down myths and misconceptions that frequently dissuade underrepresented  minority students from pursuing graduate school in the sciences. Video footage from the workshops will be developed into a short publicly available video both in Spanish and English to further broaden participation in the sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This postdoctoral research fellowship in biology has led to several major advances in the field of pollinator ecology, despite coinciding with the start of the Covid-19 pandemic and the major changes that were required (the fellowship started in 2020). The major intellectual merit advances relate to 1) bee disease dynamics, 2) ecology of neotropical bee communities, and 3) novel machine learning technologies for monitoring pollinator activity. 1) This work has expanded our understanding of bee pathogens, one of the primary stressors linked to pollinator declines. Sunflower pollen provides a strong medicinal effect for common eastern bumble bees (Bombus impatiens) infected with the gut pathogen Crithidia bombi, yet the mechanism for this pattern was unknown. I was able to clearly show that sunflower pollen exines (the spiny pollen shell), and not its chemical constituents (secondary metabolites) were driving the antipathogenic response. I screened seven additional species in the sunflower family, finding that 4/7 had comparable pathogen reductions. I complemented this empirical work with four published reviews that illustrated the diversity, mode of transmission, and implications of different bumble bee pathogens in North America, an article finding active pathogen replication in solitary bee species, and an empirical evaluation of the role of bee functional traits on pathogen prevalence in diverse bee communities. In addition to bee disease dynamics, aligned with the original goals of this fellowship 2) I have expanded our understanding of the foraging strategies of diverse neotropical bee communities (three publications), including the microbiome of stingless bees with unique dietary preferences that include carrion as well as flowering plants. Lastly 3) I have advanced the field of automated bioacoustics for monitoring pollinators. This includes the development of a convolutional neural network model in collaboration with the K. Lisa Yang Center for Conservation Bioacoustics for classifying honey bees and bumble bees in flight, and the publication of a systematic review of the automated insect bioacoustics literature. The review showed that most automated models have focused on insect pests (e.g. weevils that consume stored grain), while fewer have focused on the study of biodiversity or disease vectors. Nonetheless, we found automated bioacoustics models for 302 insect species distributed across nine Orders. We found that machine learning, especially deep learning, is the current golden standard in the field.

 

Given that pathogens are one of the factors linked to pollinator decline, understanding the mechanism mediating a natural antipathogenic compounds could not only shape future seed mixes recommended for bees vulnerable to disease outbreaks (e.g. those near commercial bumble bee operations or near apiaries), but could also incentivize the development of synthetic medicines for controlling outbreaks within commercial bumble bee breeding facilities (e.g. compounds that mimic the spiny shells of sunflower pollen). Furthermore, the three published studies reviewing pathogen dynamics in bumble bees were developed specifically with the goal of not only advancing scientific understanding, but also encouraging policy recommendations that reduce risks of outbreaks to wild bumble bee communities. Similarly, given the important role of pollinators for ecosystem service provisioning and their documented declines, it is paramount to find suitable non-lethal alternatives/complementary strategies to current monitoring protocols (e.g. lethal pan traps). The automated machine learning bioacoustics model that we are developing and that will be available via the RavenPro software will be an important contribution to a diversified toolkit for monitoring pollinators around the world.

 

Beyond the intellectual merit of the research conducted throughout the life of this award, there were significant contributions to broadening participation in science. I published three well-reviewed videos about how to succeed in graduate school, breaking down the hidden curriculum which limits many students from underserved backgrounds from entering and succeeding in graduate school (freely available on YouTube). I wrote and am publishing an open-access bilingual (Spanish/English) children's book on agroecology. I have made connections with teachers at low-income schools interested in incorporating the material into their classrooms. Furthermore, I participated in a broad suite of science outreach events reaching K12, community colleges, and university students, as well as the broader members of the public, reaching >1000 people throughout the course of the fellowship. Activities included: guest lectures related to how to succeed in graduate school at UMass Amherst and Cornell university, leading an interactive workshop on plant-pollinator ecology for students at the National University of Costa Rica (anonymous exit survey of attendees 100% rated the workshop 10/10), hosting an interactive booth during Springfield Technical Community College's Sustainathon (+700 students), co-leading an enrichment program for 7th grade students in Girls inc. of the Valley's Eureka! STEM career preparedness program for youth in underserved communities, presenting to Harvard Forest's summer interns on advice for succeeding in graduate school, and serving on the UMass, Amherst Environmental Conservation Justice, Equity, Diversity, Inclusion & Accessibility Leadership Team.
